ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: How to read research reports, writing essays on epidemiology, presenting science in an easily comprehendible manner.
How to think critically about public health issues and other factors that drive/affect them like politics, media, and global affairs.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Strengths: the virtual format allowed for some amazing guest speakers.
The format is conducive to learning material. The modules are all very specifically targeted. Sometimes the presentations can feel like quantity over quality

I loved the small group and the coursework was obviously super relevant with the pandemic occurring in real-time as we studied it. I really like our projects, and the reading we did (although some days there was a lot assigned) was very interesting. This course could be improved by not having so many days with insane reading due just two days later (maybe some of it can be required, while some is extended?). Professor Bazell is awesome and I really loved his style of teaching! He's really smart and has a lot of cool experience. I also loved that we could take the course in many different directions and really pick what interests us in epidemiology to study. For our final project paper, we could write about whatever we wanted, so long as it related to the class in some way.

Strengths: enough focus on covid and other public health issues
weaknesses: none 
Can't think of a way it could be improved, honestly.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think the whole course worked well in this regard

I loved being able to have so many guest speakers (not sure if we would have so many during an in-person semester). I liked how engaging the class time was, as we were having discussions with everyone during each session.
The live discussion sections and guest speakers kept us engaged. We also had group projects which were fun!

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes. Professor Bazell is an amazing professor and a great connection if you wish to pursue public health.

Definitely. Anyone interested in modern public health policies and wants to engage with professionals in the sphere should go straight  here. I recommend making it a course available to people outside of first year
YES!!! Professor Bazell is amazing and the material is super interesting.

ABSOLUTELY 100%. Students interested in pre-med, engineering, global affairs, and/or public health should definitely take this course. The material is very interesting and the professor will push you think deeply about public health issues and controversial topics.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: We had live class with discussions and sometimes a short lecture from Professor Bazell.
We also had to watch recorded lectures once in a while. We also heard a lot from visitors!!!
